summary_points: 1. AES Corporation reported a net loss of $73 million for Q1 2025, compared to a net income of $278 million in Q1 2024, primarily due to higher prior-year revenues from the Warrior Run coal plant PPA, one-time restructuring costs, and a 2024 gain on Uplight dilution.

2.  Despite the Q1 2025 net loss, AES reaffirmed its 2025 guidance for Adjusted EBITDA of $2,650 to $2,850 million and Adjusted EPS of $2.10 to $2.26, anticipating growth from new renewables projects and rate base growth.
3.  AES achieved its full-year 2025 asset sale proceeds target of $400 to $500 million by selling a minority stake in AES Global Insurance Company for $450 million.
1. SBA Communications Corp. exited the Philippines and Colombia markets in Q1 2025, incurring an $18.2 million loss.
2.  A new $1.5 billion share repurchase plan was authorized in April 2025, replacing a prior plan.
3.  A Brazilian tax dispute could result in up to $121.8 million in potential liabilities (including penalties and interest).

1. Mettler-Toledo's reported sales for the first quarter of 2025 declined by 5% year-over-year, while local currency sales decreased by 3%, but increased by 3% excluding the impact of delayed shipments in Q1 2024.
2.  Adjusted EPS for Q1 2025 was $8.19, an 8% decrease compared to $8.89 in Q1 2024.
3.  Management forecasts local currency sales growth of approximately 0% to 1% for Q2 2025 and anticipates a 3% headwind to Adjusted EPS growth in Q2 2025 due to higher tariff costs.
1. Motorola Solutions' Q1 2025 net earnings drastically improved to $430 million, a significant turnaround from a $39 million net loss in Q1 2024.

2.  As of March 29, 2025, $5.3 billion of Motorola Solutions' $8.9 billion in remaining performance obligations is attributed to the Software and Services segment, exceeding the Products and Systems Integration segment.
3.  The company anticipates increased materials and component costs in 2025 due to new US global tariffs, but expects to mitigate these; however, the extent of mitigation is unclear.
1. Grainger's net sales increased 1.7% year-over-year for the quarter ending March 31, 2025, but daily, constant currency net sales showed a stronger 4% increase.
2.  Accrued sales incentives decreased by $3 million between December 31, 2024, and March 31, 2025.
3. A quarterly dividend of $2.26 per share was declared on April 30, 2025, payable June 1, 2025.
1. Biogen's Q1 2025 net income decreased by 39.3% year-over-year to $240.5 million, primarily due to increased costs and expenses.
2. Biogen committed to $1.5 billion in lease payments for a new headquarters over 15.5 years, starting March 2025.
3. Biogen anticipates $350 million in intangible asset amortization for the remainder of 2025, with further annual amortizations totaling over $3 billion through 2030.
1.  Con Edison's revenue significantly increased by $518 million (12.1%) year-over-year to $4,798 million in the three months ended March 31, 2025.
2.  Con Edison faces a potential liability of up to $172 million related to a California battery storage project, as of January 2025.
3.  Con Edison raised approximately $1.3 billion in May 2025 through a common stock issuance and forward sale agreement.
1. Consolidated Edison's Q1 2025 net income increased by $71 million (10%) year-over-year to $791 million.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, Con Edison had total assets of $71 billion, a $1 billion (1.4%) increase year-over-year.
3. Con Edison's Q1 2025 adjusted earnings per share forecast (between $5.50 and $5.70) as of May 1st, 2025, excludes unspecified items.
1. Ameren Corporation reported Q1 2025 GAAP diluted earnings per share of $1.07, compared to $0.98 in Q1 2024, and adjusted (non-GAAP) diluted EPS of $1.07 versus $1.02 in Q1 2024.

2.  The year-over-year increase in Ameren Missouri's Q1 2025 earnings ($42 million vs $25 million GAAP and $36 million adjusted in Q1 2024) was primarily driven by higher retail sales due to colder winter temperatures, partially offset by higher interest and storm-related expenses.

3. Ameren reaffirmed its 2025 diluted EPS guidance range of $4.85 to $5.05 per share (as of May 1, 2025), contingent on normal temperatures for the remaining nine months and various regulatory, economic, and weather-related factors.
1. On May 1, 2025, Procter & Gamble closed a public offering of $700,000,000 in 4.050% notes due May 1, 2030, and $550,000,000 in 4.600% notes due May 1, 2035.
2.  Legal opinions related to the notes were filed as exhibits (5)(a) and (5)(b).
3. The offering closed on May 1st, 2025,  indicating successful completion of the financing within the projected timeframe.
1. IDEX Corp.'s Q1 2025 diluted EPS decreased by 21% year-over-year to $1.26.
2.  IDEX Corp. expects to incur between $3.5 and $7.5 million in additional restructuring charges for severance through the remainder of 2025 (as of May 1, 2025).
3.  As of March 31, 2025, IDEX Corp. had $489.7 million remaining in share repurchase authorization.
1. Camden Property Trust's Q1 2025 diluted EPS of $0.36 represents a significant 53% decrease year-over-year.
2.  The company projects an 8.6% increase in same-property expenses for 2025, resulting in a 3.5% decline in NOI margin, driven by operational challenges unrelated to revenue growth.
3.  Camden's wholly-owned development pipeline, totaling $350.7 million as of March 31, 2025, is expected to be substantially complete by the end of 2027.
1. On May 1, 2025, Fredric J. Tomczyk retired as CEO of Cboe Global Markets, Inc., to be replaced by Craig Donohue, effective May 7, 2025.

2.  Craig Donohue's compensation package includes an annual base salary of $1,300,000, a target bonus of 150% (prorated for 2025), and a total target long-term incentive award value of $10,050,000 (prorated for 2025), plus a $6,000,000 sign-on equity award.

3. Mr. Donohue's employment agreement, effective May 7, 2025, includes customary restrictive covenants and a severance benefit equal to 200% of his annual base salary and target bonus if terminated "without cause" or resigns for "good reason."

1. Ingersoll Rand Inc. reported record first-quarter 2025 orders ($1,882 million, up 10% year-over-year) and free cash flow ($223 million, up 124% year-over-year), while revenue increased by 3% to $1,717 million.
2.  Despite record free cash flow,  the company's full-year 2025 Adjusted EBITDA guidance was lowered from $2,130M-$2,190M to $2,070M-$2,130M, representing a significant decrease in predicted growth.
3. Ingersoll Rand plans to repurchase up to $750 million of its shares by the end of 2025 and will continue to pursue bolt-on acquisitions.
1. On May 1, 2025, Constellation Brands issued $500 million in 4.800% Senior Notes due 2030, at a public offering price of 99.824% of the principal amount.
2.  The Notes mature on May 1, 2030, and interest is payable semi-annually, commencing November 1, 2025.

3.  The Supplemental Indenture contains customary events of default, including default in payment of principal or interest, and specified events involving bankruptcy, insolvency, or reorganization of the Company.
1. Becton Dickinson plans to separate its Biosciences and Diagnostic Solutions business, aiming for completion in fiscal year 2026.
2.  The company's worldwide revenue for the quarter ending March 31, 2025, was $5.272 billion, a 4.5% year-over-year increase.
3. As of March 31, 2025, BD faced 6,790 product liability claims related to its hernia repair devices, an increase of 180 claims since September 30, 2024.
1. At American Express Company's Annual Meeting of Shareholders on April 29, 2025, all twelve director nominees received a majority of votes cast.

2.  Shareholder proposals relating to Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) goals in executive pay and civil liberties in advertising services received only 0.95% and 1.01% of votes in favor, respectively.
3. PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP was ratified as American Express Company’s independent registered public accounting firm for 2025, receiving 96.81% of the votes.
1. Delta Air Lines' Board of Directors approved a $1 billion share repurchase program, to be completed by June 30, 2028.
2.  Combined with the existing dividend, Delta plans to return over $2 billion to shareholders in the next three years.

3.  Delta's capital allocation priorities are reinvesting in the business, debt reduction, and increasing shareholder returns as leverage targets (1x gross leverage and over $40 billion in unencumbered assets) are met.
1. Apple Inc. reported second-quarter 2025 revenue of $95.4 billion, a 5% year-over-year increase, and diluted earnings per share of $1.65, an 8% year-over-year increase.
2.  The company declared a 4% increase in its cash dividend to $0.26 per share, payable on May 15, 2025, and authorized a $100 billion common stock repurchase program.
3. Apple's press release identifies several future risks including global economic conditions, competition, information technology system failures, and unfavorable legal proceedings.
1. HCA Healthcare's first-quarter 2025 revenues increased by 5.7% year-over-year to $18.321 billion.
2.  HCA Healthcare anticipates capital expenditures of $5.0 billion to $5.2 billion in 2025, plus an estimated $5.6 billion over the next five years for ongoing projects.
3.  HCA Healthcare's liability for unrecognized tax benefits may significantly increase or decrease within the next 12 months (by May 1, 2026).
1. EOG Resources repurchased $788 million of its common stock in Q1 2025, a significant portion of its $5.1 billion remaining share repurchase authorization.
2. Despite a 3% increase in oil and gas production revenue, Q1 2025 operating revenues decreased by 7% compared to Q1 2024, primarily due to mark-to-market losses on derivatives.
3. EOG projects a modest increase in oil and gas production for 2025, with capital expenditures estimated between $5.8 billion and $6.2 billion.

1. Dow Inc. finalized the sale of a 40% equity stake in Diamond Infrastructure Solutions to a Macquarie Asset Management fund on May 1, 2025, receiving initial proceeds of approximately $2.4 billion with the potential for an additional $600 million.
2.  The sale of the 40% stake generated approximately $2.4 billion in cash proceeds for Dow Inc. on May 1, 2025.

3. Macquarie Asset Management has an option to increase its equity stake to 49% within six months of the closing (May 1, 2025), potentially increasing Dow's total proceeds to approximately $3 billion.
1. Alphabet Inc. completed a public offering of $5,000,000,000 in aggregate principal amount of bonds on May 1, 2025.
2.  The bonds issued have varying maturity dates (2030, 2035, 2055, and 2065) and interest rates (4.000%, 4.500%, 5.250%, and 5.300%).
3.  The offering was made pursuant to a February 12, 2016 Indenture between Alphabet and The Bank of New York Mellon Trust Company, N.A., as trustee.
1. Ventas' Q1 2025 net income of $46.87 million represents a significant turnaround from a $12.54 million net loss in Q1 2024.
2.  Ventas acquired 20 senior housing communities totaling $874.5 million in the first four months of 2025.
3.  A Q1 2025 income tax benefit may lead to substantially higher future income tax liabilities for Ventas' TRS entities.
1. As of May 1, 2025, Arthur J. Gallagher & Co. reported 14% revenue growth year-over-year in its core brokerage and risk management segments, including 9% organic revenue growth.
2.  The company's adjusted EBITDAC margin increased by 338 basis points to 41.1% year-over-year in Q1 2025.

3. The acquisition of AssuredPartners, expected to close in the second half of 2025,  is subject to customary regulatory approvals and standard closing conditions; a request for additional information was received on March 7, 2025.
1. EOG Resources, Inc.'s Q1 2025 diluted earnings per share (GAAP) increased 19% to $2.65 compared to Q4 2024's $2.23.
2. EOG released a forecast for Q2 2025 and the full year 2025 on May 1, 2025, however, specific numerical details were not provided in the reviewed sections of the filing.
3.  EOG revised its Q1 2025 GAAP diluted EPS forecast for Q2 2025 and the full year 2025; however, no details on the nature or magnitude of the revision were given.
1. AES Corp. reported a net loss of $73 million for Q1 2025, compared to a net income of $278 million in Q1 2024.

2.  $531 million in subsidiary non-recourse debt defaults existed as of March 31, 2025,  with a potential future risk of triggering a cross-default on parent company recourse debt if the total reaches 20% of cash distributions.

3.  AES Corp. completed several significant asset transactions in April 2025, including the sale of minority interests in its captive insurance company for $450 million and the acquisition of additional equity in Empresa Electrica Cochrane SpA.
1. Mohawk Industries experienced a 5.7% decrease in net sales in Q1 2025, reaching $2.5 billion compared to $2.7 billion in Q1 2024.
2.  The company projects adjusted EPS between $2.52 and $2.62 for Q2 2025.
3. Newly implemented global tariffs are expected to reduce annual profits by approximately $50 million.
1. Exelon's Q1 2025 net income increased by $250 million year-over-year, reaching $908 million.
2.  Exelon's cash, cash equivalents, and restricted cash increased by $274 million between March 31, 2024, and March 31, 2025, totaling $1,582 million as of March 31, 2025.
3.  Pending IRS approval, Exelon subsidiaries could see a reduction in regulatory liabilities ranging from $1.2 billion to $1.7 billion.
1. AIG declared a 12.5% increase in its quarterly common stock dividend to $0.45 per share, effective in Q2 2025.

2.  First-quarter 2025 net income attributable to AIG common shareholders was $698 million ($1.16 per diluted share), a decrease from $1.2 billion ($1.74 per diluted share) in Q1 2024, largely due to the deconsolidation of Corebridge Financial.
3. AIG returned approximately $2.5 billion of capital to shareholders in Q1 2025, and maintains a positive outlook, expecting to achieve 10%+ Core Operating ROE for the full year 2025.
1. Eversource Energy's Q1 2025 net income was $400 million, a $20 million increase compared to Q1 2024.
2.  The company expects a $200 million after-tax gain from the Aquarion water business divestiture, which is expected to close later in 2025.
3. Eversource plans to repurchase $500 million of its common stock in 2025.
1. Hershey's Q1 2025 net income decreased 71.9% year-over-year to $224.2 million.
2. Hershey is acquiring LesserEvil, LLC, expected to close by mid-2025.
3.  The FDA's phase-out of petroleum-based synthetic dyes, announced in April 2025, may increase Hershey's costs.
1. Live Nation's Q1 2025 revenue decreased by 11% year-over-year to $3.4 billion, but operating income improved significantly, reaching $114.8 million compared to a $41.4 million loss in Q1 2024.
2. As of March 31, 2025, Live Nation held $6.1 billion in deferred revenue (a 21% year-over-year increase), and $1.6 billion in client cash.
3.  Live Nation had $694.6 million in future operating lease payments not yet commenced as of March 31, 2025, with lease terms ranging from 7 to 39 years.
1. Molina Healthcare, Inc. stockholders approved the Company’s 2025 Equity Incentive Plan on April 30, 2025,  with 85.6% of outstanding shares voting in favor.

2.  In the vote on Proposal No. 2 (advisory vote on executive compensation), 18,249,700 shares voted for, and 26,653,672 voted against, representing 33.4% and 48.7% of shares outstanding on the record date, respectively.
3. The 2025 Equity Incentive Plan allows for the granting of up to 1,795,000 shares of stock, subject to adjustments for changes in capital structure and addbacks for forfeited or expired awards.
1. Juniper Networks reported preliminary first-quarter 2025 net revenues of $1,280.2 million, an 11% year-over-year increase but a 9% sequential decrease.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, Juniper held $1,970.4 million in total cash, cash equivalents, and investments, up from $1,534.9 million on March 31, 2024.

3.  A proposed merger with Hewlett Packard Enterprise is facing legal challenges from the U.S. Department of Justice, with a trial scheduled to begin July 9, 2025;  Juniper has suspended share repurchases as part of the merger agreement.

1. At the April 29, 2025 Annual Meeting, American Electric Power shareholders approved the election of twelve individuals to the board of directors, the ratification of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as the independent auditor, and an advisory vote on executive compensation.
2.  Shareholder votes for the election of board members ranged from 376,016,034 to 402,008,392, with significant numbers of votes against and abstentions for each candidate.
3. No specific future impacts or risks are identified in this section of the filing.
1. Amazon's net sales for the first quarter of 2025 increased by 9% year-over-year to $155.7 billion, representing a 10% increase excluding the negative impact of foreign exchange rates.
2.  For the trailing twelve months ending March 31, 2025, Amazon's operating cash flow increased by 15% to $113.9 billion, while free cash flow decreased to $25.9 billion.

3. Amazon forecasts net sales between $159.0 billion and $164.0 billion for the second quarter of 2025, anticipating a 7% to 11% year-over-year growth and a 10 basis point unfavorable impact from foreign exchange rates.
1. ITW's net income fell by $119 million in Q1 2025 compared to Q1 2024, reaching $700 million.
2.  ITW's operating revenue decreased by 3.4% year-over-year in Q1 2025, totaling $3.839 billion.
3. New US tariffs implemented in April 2025 may negatively impact future customer demand for ITW products.
1. As of March 31, 2025, Live Nation reported record deferred revenue of $5.67 billion ($5.4B Concerts + $270M Ticketmaster), a 24% and 13% year-over-year increase respectively.
2. Live Nation projects double-digit year-over-year growth in operating income and adjusted operating income for the full year 2025.

3.  Live Nation's venue expansion plan, involving at least 20 new large venues by 2026, is expected to generate $700 million in annual revenue and increase capacity by seven million fans annually, with anticipated average investment returns exceeding 20%.
1. General Motors' Q1 2025 net income decreased slightly year-over-year to $2.784 billion, from $2.980 billion.
2.  New U.S. government tariffs are projected to reduce GM's adjusted EBIT by $4.0 to $5.0 billion in 2025.
3. GM acquired the remaining stake in Cruise in February 2025, shifting its autonomous vehicle focus to ADAS for personal vehicles, after ceasing robotaxi development in December 2024.
1. GoDaddy Inc. announced Q1 2025 financial results on May 1, 2025, including total revenue of $1.2 billion (up 8% year-over-year) and normalized EBITDA of $364.4 million (up 16% year-over-year).
2.  GoDaddy completed its 2022 share repurchase program, repurchasing over 25% of its fully diluted shares, and announced a new $3 billion multi-year repurchase authorization through 2027.
3. GoDaddy expects full-year 2025 revenue in the range of $4.860 billion to $4.940 billion, representing year-over-year growth of 7% at the midpoint, and free cash flow of at least $1.5 billion.

1. Motorola Solutions reported record Q1 2025 sales of $2.5 billion, a 6% increase year-over-year, driven by North American growth, partially offset by international declines due to currency headwinds and lower Ukraine revenue.
2.  Q1 2025 Non-GAAP EPS was $3.18, a 13% increase year-over-year, while Q1 2025 operating cash flow reached a record $510 million, up $128 million year-over-year.
3.  The company expects approximately $40 million in foreign exchange headwinds and increased material and component costs in 2025, though it plans to substantially mitigate these.
1. Aptiv PLC experienced a significant year-over-year net income decrease from $218 million in Q1 2024 to a net loss of $11 million in Q1 2025.
2.  Aptiv anticipates incurring an additional $30 million in restructuring charges through the remainder of 2025 due to workforce reductions.
3.  The planned separation of Aptiv's Electrical Distribution Systems business is expected to be completed by March 31, 2026, with $19 million in separation costs already incurred in Q1 2025.
1. IDEXX's Q1 2025 revenue increased by $34,332,000 compared to Q1 2024, reaching $998,427,000.
2.  IDEXX anticipates approximately $4.7 billion in future revenue from multi-year customer commitments, with a significant portion (21%, 25%, and 21%) expected in 2025, 2026, and 2027.
3.  IDEXX is assessing the financial statement implications of ASU 2024-03 and ASU 2023-09.
1. Stryker Corp reported an 11.9% increase in net sales to $5.9 billion in Q1 2025, driven by 10.1% organic net sales growth; however, reported EPS decreased by 17.6% to $1.69.

2.  Stryker raised its full-year 2025 organic net sales growth guidance to 8.5% - 9.5%, but lowered its adjusted net earnings per diluted share guidance to $13.20-$13.45 from $13.45-$13.70 (excluding a dilutive impact from an acquisition).

3.  Stryker's updated sales guidance reflects a modestly favorable pricing impact and a slightly unfavorable foreign exchange impact, while the lowered earnings guidance incorporates an estimated $200 million tariff impact.
1. PACCAR's Q1 2025 net income was significantly lower than Q1 2024, decreasing from $1,195.3 million to $505.1 million.
2.  PACCAR anticipates a $600-$900 million investment in their battery joint venture in 2025, in addition to other planned capital expenditures.
3. A $350 million pre-tax charge ($264.5 million after-tax) was recorded in Q1 2025 due to European Commission claims.
1. eBay's net revenue increased by only 1% year-over-year to $2,585 million in Q1 2025, despite higher GMV and promoted listings, suggesting challenges from fee structure changes.
2.  eBay anticipates a $170 million decrease in unrecognized tax benefits in the next year (as of May 1, 2025), due to ongoing tax examinations.
3.  In Q1 2025, eBay repurchased 9 million shares for $625 million, indicating a significant capital allocation strategy.
1. Amgen Inc. reported total revenues of $8.1 billion for the first quarter of 2025, a 9% increase year-over-year.
2.  Non-GAAP earnings per share (EPS) increased 24% year-over-year to $4.90 in Q1 2025, while GAAP EPS was $3.20 compared to a loss of $0.21 in Q1 2024.
3. Amgen forecasts total revenues in the range of $34.3 billion to $35.7 billion for the full year 2025, with non-GAAP EPS projected between $20.00 and $21.20.
1. KLA Corporation's Q3 FY25 revenue increased by 30% ($703,199,000) compared to Q3 FY24.
2.  As of April 30, 2025, KLA Corporation increased its stock repurchase program authorization by $5 billion.
3. US government export control tightening on items destined for China poses a material risk to KLA's future business.
1. DexCom Inc. reported first-quarter 2025 revenue of $1.036 billion, a 12% year-over-year increase on a reported basis (compared to $921.0 million in Q1 2024).
2.  As of March 31, 2025, DexCom held $2.7 billion in cash, cash equivalents, and marketable securities.

3. DexCom announced a $750 million share repurchase program, expiring no later than June 30, 2026, and updated its fiscal year 2025 guidance to reflect a Non-GAAP Gross Profit Margin of approximately 62%, primarily due to increased near-term supply costs.
1. Airbnb's net income dropped 42% year-over-year to $154 million in Q1 2025, primarily due to increased payroll expenses and investment losses.
2.  Airbnb faces potential losses totaling between $259 million and $300 million related to lodging and transactional taxes as of March 31, 2025.
3.  During Q1 2025, Airbnb repurchased 6.1 million shares of its Class A common stock for $807 million.
1. Moderna's Q1 2025 net product sales decreased by 49% year-over-year to $86 million, primarily due to lower U.S. sales from reduced vaccination rates.
2. Moderna incurred $42 million in inventory write-downs in Q1 2025, a $12 million increase compared to the same period in 2024.
3. As of March 31, 2025, Moderna held $2.6 billion in cancelable open purchase orders for clinical operations and contract manufacturing.
1. Iron Mountain experienced a significant swing from a $74.06 million net income in Q1 2024 to a $15.95 million net loss in Q1 2025, despite an 11.8% year-over-year increase in Adjusted EBITDA.
2. Project Matterhorn, a restructuring program, is expected to cost $150 million by its projected completion date of December 2025.
3. As of March 31, 2025, Iron Mountain held a net liability of approximately $10.43 million related to interest rate swap agreements.

1. Hologic Inc.'s Q2 2025 revenue of $1,005.3 million slightly exceeded the company's guidance range of $995 to $1,005 million provided in February 2025, but overall revenue decreased by 1.2% year-over-year.

2.  GAAP diluted EPS for Q2 2025 was a loss of ($0.08), a significant decrease from $0.72 in Q2 2024, primarily due to $220.9 million in non-cash impairment charges; non-GAAP diluted EPS remained flat year-over-year at $1.03.
3. Hologic lowered its full-year 2025 guidance for both GAAP and non-GAAP EPS, citing tariffs and geopolitical conditions, while maintaining its full-year revenue guidance.
1. PTC Inc.'s annual run rate (ARR) reached $2.29 billion as of March 31, 2025, a 10% year-over-year increase.
2.  The company repurchased $150 million of its common stock in the first half of 2025, exceeding the $300 million stock repurchase plan for the full fiscal year 2025.
3.  A significant reduction in short-term debt occurred between September 30, 2024, and March 31, 2025, decreasing from $521.5 million to $25 million.
1. Airbnb's Q1 2025 net income decreased 42% year-over-year to $154 million.
2.  Airbnb projects a 9-11% year-over-year revenue increase for Q2 2025, reaching between $2.99 billion and $3.05 billion.

3. Starting May 13th, 2025, a $200-$250 million investment in new businesses, focused on expanding beyond accommodations into experiences and other travel offerings ("Airbnb 2.0"), will likely impact the Adjusted EBITDA margin negatively in the second half of 2025.
1. Hubert L. Allen, Abbott Laboratories' Executive Vice President, General Counsel, and Secretary, will retire after a transition period, as of April 25, 2025.
2.  The filing is an 8-K Current Report, filed on May 1, 2025, concerning a change in officers.
3. No specific future impacts or risks are mentioned beyond the planned retirement of an executive.
1. Monolithic Power Systems (MPS) reported Q1 2025 revenue of $637.6 million, a 39.2% year-over-year increase, but a slight 2.6% increase compared to Q4 2024.
2.  The Storage and Computing segment experienced significant growth, with revenue increasing 77.7% year-over-year in Q1 2025.
3. MPS forecasts Q2 2025 revenue between $640 million and $660 million, with GAAP operating expenses projected between $189 million and $195 million.
1. FMC Corp's Q1 2025 revenue decreased 14% year-over-year to $791.4 million, primarily due to lower pricing and volume.
2.  FMC Corp anticipates essentially flat revenue for 2025 compared to 2024, with a mid-single digit decline in pricing and a low-single digit headwind from foreign currency.
3. The company completed the sale of its Global Specialty Solutions business in November 2024 for approximately $340 million.

1. On May 1, 2025, NRG Energy, Inc. stockholders approved an amendment to the company's charter eliminating supermajority voting requirements for common stock, removing obsolete references to a classified board, and making other technical updates.
2. At the May 1, 2025 annual meeting, all eleven director nominees were elected, with the lowest vote count for a single director being 154,279,236 votes for (approximately 88% of the votes cast).
3.  The advisory vote on executive compensation and the ratification of KPMG LLP as the independent auditor for the 2025 fiscal year were both approved at the May 1, 2025, annual meeting.

1. Air Products reported a net loss of $1.7 billion for Q2 2025 (ended March 31, 2025), compared to a net income of $580.9 million in Q2 2024, primarily due to a $2.3 billion after-tax charge for business and asset actions.
2.  The company expects approximately $500 million in cash expenditures related to project exits, with $90 million already paid in Q2 2025.

3. Air Products derecognized approximately $600 million in plant and equipment and $655 million in long-term debt due to the deconsolidation of its Blue Hydrogen Industrial Gases Company subsidiary during Q2 2025.
1. Carrier's net sales decreased by 4% year-over-year to $5.2 billion in the first quarter of 2025.
2.  Carrier expects to pay $615 million in litigation settlements over the next five years, offset by $2.4 billion in insurance recoveries.
3.  As of March 31, 2025, Carrier had $56 million accrued for restructuring costs, with the majority expected to be used within one year.
1. Ball Corporation's Board of Directors amended the company's bylaws on April 30, 2025, to allow for a board size ranging from nine to fifteen members.

2. At the Annual Meeting of Shareholders on April 30, 2025, Todd Penegor received significantly fewer "For" votes (166,206,794) for election as a director compared to other directors, who received over 200 million votes.
3.  Shareholder votes at the April 30, 2025 Annual Meeting approved an amendment to remove the default Board size provision in the Articles of Incorporation with 223,217,239 votes in favor.
1. Entergy's Q1 2025 operating revenues increased by $52,246,000 compared to Q1 2024.

2.  The sale of Entergy Louisiana and Entergy New Orleans' natural gas distribution businesses, expected to close no earlier than six months after March 5, 2025, has a potential termination date of October 28, 2025.
3.  Entergy's debt-to-capital ratio increased to 66.7% as of March 31, 2025, from 65.3% on December 31, 2024.

1. Church & Dwight Co. Inc. is exiting or selling its Flawless, Spinbrush, and Waterpik showerhead businesses, impacting $150 million in annual net sales and potentially resulting in a $60-$80 million charge in Q2 2025.
2.  First-quarter 2025 net sales decreased 2.4% year-over-year to $1,467.1 million.
3.  The company expects to reduce its twelve-month run-rate gross tariff exposure by 80%, to approximately $38 million, by May 1, 2025.
1. Targa Resources Corp.'s acquisition of Targa Badlands LLC, completed in March 2025, resulted in a $70.5 million after-tax reduction to net income attributable to common shareholders.
2.  Long-term debt increased by $1,761.4 million between December 31, 2024, and March 31, 2025.
3. The company anticipates the potential impact of the corporate alternative minimum tax (CAMT) as early as 2026.

1. Mastercard reported first-quarter 2025 net revenue of $7.3 billion, a 14% year-over-year increase (17% on a currency-neutral basis), driven by growth in its payment network and value-added services.

Church & Dwight revised its 2025 full-year outlook, anticipating 0% to 2% organic sales growth (previously 3% to 4%), a 60 basis point adjusted gross margin contraction (previously a 25 basis point increase), and 0% to 2% adjusted EPS growth (previously 7% to 8%), primarily due to continued retailer destocking, slower category growth, and tariff pressures.

Biogen updated its full-year 2025 Non-GAAP diluted EPS guidance to $14.50 to $15.50, reflecting a ~$0.95 decrease due to a $165 million upfront payment to Stoke Therapeutics and a $0.20 increase from more favorable foreign exchange; total revenue is expected to decline by a mid-single-digit percentage at constant currency compared to 2024.
